creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
inscription:
Signature, Date, Inscription, Stamps

inscribed in plate at upper left: [HERCVLIS]
markings: brown star-shaped stamp on verso, LL, unidentified. Also on verso: loan number for 1941 Baltimore exhibition.
provenance: Collector with unidentified brown, star-shaped mark. [David Tunick, New York; sold to Andrus]; John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
signed: monogram and date in plate at upper left: [1542 / HSB]
text:
The legendary strongman Hercules was born to the god Zeus and a mortal named Alcmena. This union so incensed Zeus’s wife Hera that she made life almost unbearable for the hero. Her ire resulted in him undertaking a series of tasks, known as the Twelve Labors of Hercules. Sebald Beham challenged his audience’s knowledge of the classical text, engraving three actual labors and nine scenes of Hercules’ exploits before and after his labors.

When the centaur Nessus offends Hercules’ wife Deianeira, Hercules shoots him with an arrow dipped in the hydra’s lethal blood.
title: Hercules Killing Nessus, From the Labors of Hercules
